reference.title: Typewriter Anatomy Definitions
reference.shortdesc: Typewriters contain a multitude of mechanical components. It is important for typewriter users to be familiar with these components to effectively and efficiently use their typewriters.

dlentry.dd: The casing or outer shell of a typewriter that protects the internal mechanisms.
Any screw that connects the body panels to the interior typewriter machinery.
A large mechanical component that holds the platen and feed rollers, and moves horizontally across the machine as you type.
A small lever located on the right hand side of the typewriter, often directly next to the right platen knob, that automatically centers the carriage.
A large lever, often located on the left side of the carriage, that moves the carriage back to the right margin and advances the paper to the next line.
A smaller, rubber-covered roller that works in conjunction with the platen to grip and guide paper.
A lever that controls the vertical distance, or spacing, between lines of text. This can sometimes be the same lever as the carriage return.
Buttons on newer typewriter models that allow the user to set margins by moving the carriage and pressing the buttons.
A lever or switch that allows the user to manually change the winding direction of the ink ribbon between its spools.
A key or lever that allows the user to temporarily type past preset margin stops.
A small metal or plastic tab that is used to set margins. These tabs act as stoppers and prevent the carriage from moving beyond a set margin on the left and right sides of the page.
A metal bar that flips down to hold paper against the platen.
Small rubber rollers on the paper bail that press the paper against the platen roller.
An adjustable clamp that holds paper against the platen roller to maintain alignment and prevent it from slipping, used in conjunction with the paper bail.
A small lever that releases the presser on the paper from the feed rollers, allowing the user to remove or readjust the paper.
A piece of metal or plastic that lightly holds paper perpendicular against the platen during paper feeding to guide the paper into the machine.
A small metal arm shaft that sticks out from the center of the left hand platen knob that connects to a metal shaft which holds the platen in place.
A small handle located at the end of the platen used to rotate the platen roller.
A small lever on the right hand side of the typewriter that releases the platen from its slot in the typewriter when pressed.
A large, rubber-covered roller that works in conjunction with feed rollers to grip and guide paper.
A lever or switch that shifts the ribbon to type a different color.
A metal lid that protects the internal ribbon mechanisms, often hinged or connected via prongs and grommets.
A thin metal plate, located on the typewriter undercarriage directly under the segment.
Character tabs that activate the type bars when pressed.
Small rubber pads on the bottom of a typewriter, used to prevent sliding and absorb vibrations from typing.
The underside of the typewriter.
A forked or pronged lever that uses grommets or eyelets to automatically change the ribbon winding direction without manual intervention.
A linear guide mechanism that contains a metal rail and tracks that slide the carriage back and forth along the horizontal plane of the rail.
A string or cord that connects the carriage to the mainspring drum.
Small metal or plastic rings that cover and protect holes in the typewriter frame at points of connection between structural components.
The metal arm that connects Type Keys to the Type Bar/Hammer.
A tightly coiled spring that maintains tension to move the carriage while typing and powers the carriage return.
A small, metal, ring-like component located at the end of the platen shaft/rod.

A metal component located at the center of a typewriter that guides and supports the ink ribbon as it passes from one spool to the other. It holds the ribbon in position for the type slugs to strike it and transfer ink to paper.
Small metal slots located on the Ribbon Carrier to hold and straighten the ribbon in place.
A small opening or groove on the Ribbon Spool that fits over the Spool Pin.
A cylindrical reel that contains inked ribbon.
An arched, comb-like metal component that guides the typebars to ensure proper typing alignment. Also known as a type basket.
Metal cylinder that holds the mainspring, also known as the Spring Drum.
The group of gears, barrels/drums, and other mechanics that hold the mainspring to the typewriter.
Metal or plastic arm that holds and directs the ink ribbon between the ribbon spool and ribbon guide.
A small metal or plastic pin that secures and aligns the ribbon spool to the ribbon shaft.
A small rod that holds and rotates the ribbon spool.
A thin, metal bar that holds type characters at its end and strikes the ink ribbon to print the characters.
Small mechanical connection between Keylever and Type Bar.
Individual metal characters located at the end of a Type Bar.
A small spring, wrapped into a circle and with a prong on either end of the circle, that sits between the platen roller and platen shaft collar that allows for manual spacing adjustment.
